name: example_project_1
input_docs:
Straight to the point, it's cheap, it tastes and feels cheap. The good: price, location, dessert (recommended food items are: baked chicken, fried chicken, potatoes, Salad, meat and cheese, pizza) also our waitress was great. The normal: behind the counter meat slicing station, shrimp (not even deshelled), Mexican station. The bad: breakfast -worst eggs ever, actually worst, eggs. The chef can't even cut through ham or hard bread (tried on all 3 occasions), beef, shrimp again. As for decoration, it's the 1970 nightmare you can imagine. 


We started with the burger set, a big mistake. It was cold and the fries were old. Mentioned to our waitress, but nothing came of it.  We ordered a large thin pizza which was a bit pricey after adding toppings. Pizza was ok, not great. Aside from not being our advocate, our server was good.  I have been here before for a football game, it was better then. Will try another venue next time.


This is a so-called restaurant that doesn't do anything a restaurant should do except preparing food, the rest is left to the guest. Do you want water? Get up and go across the yard to get it. If you want a drink, go downstairs and pay in cash. Want to sit in dirty deckchairs in a dirty garden, enjoy yourself. The waiters are a little bit helpful as they bring you your food after you go to the window and pay cash for it. Kind of like New Orleans Hamburger and Seafood, but dirty and with live music (which is nice). It's a once in a lifetime experience for me... just once.


My brother came to visit and we wanted to pick up a six pack of good beer for one night. We ended up staying and having a few while playing their Nintendo 64 (Super Smash Brothers which the owner said was donated by other customers). It's a great place with good food and really nice people. Should be a staple in the Northeast.


My menu is coconut soup and pat thai with protein. I tried the same menu here. Actually really like their coconut soup. They used enough coconut milk that the soup was really creamy and not overpowered with herbs. I'm so used to Americanized Thai cuisine that I prefer fewer herbs on my dish. Pat Thai was great too. I liked the amount of peanuts they used, the noodles were chewy and perfect and not too sweet. They gave me a generous amount of chicken and white meat was not dry so I was very happy with my meal.


I stopped here because it was close to the hotel I was staying at. The people working in the store were super nice and friendly. I like the buy one get one offer they do. I also ordered some hot wings and they were pretty good. They had a ton of sauce which is awesome. Next time I come back to town I will definitely stop here for more pizza!


Just started going to Sushi Nara this month (they only recently opened). I love this place; It's clean, the staff is friendly and courteous, and the service is quick. The sushi is always delicious (I've been here 3 times) and the prices are reasonable. In fact, my husband stopped by for take out this week, bought 4 sushi rolls and the total price was $24. That's incredible. I love the freshness of the food and there is a huge variety. Everyone on the east side, check out this place!


We had a party of 6 here for hibachi. Our waitress put our separate sushi orders on one plate so we couldn't really tell who was who and forgot several items on one order. I understand that I made mistakes but the restaurant was very quiet so we were a bit surprised. Usually hibachi is a fun lively experience and our chef said maybe three words but he cooked very well, his name was Francisco. The service was lazy, the food was pretty good and I hope it was just a free night here. But for the money I wouldn't go again.

name: Pilot study1
input_docs:
"I enjoyed ""Pleiades Rising"" for several reasons. A strong, 17 year old narrator describes her adventurous summer before beginning college in southern California. An archeological discovery along with astronomical and spiritual interventions propel Maggie and her friend Will to travel to Mexico. As the mystery behind their find deepens and the action increases, I felt that I was actually along for the ride. Just the right touch of love interest to pull in young romantics."
"My book arrived promptly. I have not yet completed the book, but have found it to be very interesting so far. You are quickly transported back a 100 years in time as you realize there are no phones (only telegraphs and letters), news comes from the newspaper, people travel by train, cities are small, thieves were clever, and honest people were very trusting. The plot moves along quickly and the subjects in the book are interesting. The fun part of this book is that it is a real life adventure! I would definitely recommend it."
"Award-winning children's author, Mayra Calvani cleverly creates the world of water droplets and how they journey from the clouds to the earth and back to the clouds again. The Water Cycle: Water Play Series Book 1 children's weather book teaches the different stages of water through the creation of rain, hail, snow, water vapor and how each travels through our atmosphere. As an added bonus, the book includes a word search and word match activities to further guide children in understanding the water cycle."
"Frommer's France day by day is a respectable travel guide for France. It has nice full color photos, comes with a separate map, and has a lot of useful info in it.Unfortunately the book is far too brief - it is useful for planning a trip to France, but you'll definitely want books detailing each individual region you plan to visit. This is only to be expected - you can't really do a whole country in one short book.Overall the book is great for what it is - a broad overview of France. If you're planning a trip to France and haven't decided on exactly what to do, this is a great resource to use to narrow down your choices."
I am a Mason and this book was very helpful to me. It describes the Templar visits to America before Columbus. In fact Columbus bore the Templar Cross on his ships and his father in law was a Mason. It describes the Vikings routes to America before Columbus and the Zeno Narrative of travels with Henry Sinclair. I am also a student of Scottish History and i find it most credible that they discovered America first. Sinclair was involved with Templars and the Masons. The book is an eye opener and rewrites history with compelling evidence - Newport Tower and Westford Knight grave stone. I don't know when schools will teach this stuff but it needs to be soon.
"Flores para los Muertos is a small but powerful book of very vibrant and well produced photographs of flower arrangements at the Key West Cemetery in Key West, Florida. Thousands of visitors to Key West visit the cemetery to wander through this facinating and historic place. The cemetery grounds are a feast to the eyes, as well as other senses. This little photo book takes you to this wonderful place and more. I recoomend this book to those who love photography, cemeteries- and love to travel."
"Not what I expected, it was a pleasant surprise. The Civil War battles are familiar topics, but the detail was more involved and personal to the characters than I had read previously. I did send a copy to my grandson who is a history buff in Gettysburg, Pa. where he has access to Civil War history at a local level. He quickly read it through, which whetted his appetite for more. He is 9 years old and more knowledgable than many older students when it comes to this part of history. Having traveled to Appotomax, and many other battlefields in Virginia made it easier to picture the area.Would highly recommend this to anyone interested in our country's history."
"I started reading this about 3 pm and couldn't put it down until I finished it! When I started reading, I thought I knew the plot and certainly how it would end. I was wrong.Leah is a strong woman in mid-life who has ""taken the road less traveled"" and takes us along with her as she travels to Spain and meets Miguel - who turns out to be many things - companion,lover,cad.Leah takes us on her journey with her relationship with Miguel - good and bad - and how she navigated her heartache while still keeping her center. Mature woman would love this read......I just have one question, what happened after the wedding, Leah? A sequel, I hope!"
"I have been cycling, training, and racing for 25+ years. The information in this book is very useful. Some of it I have seen in my travels, however there is a lot of very useful information even with my many years of experience that I found useful and informative. I believe any athlete in any sport has to read, learn, study and then find the things that work for them. We are not all the same. We must use what works for us. Interpret and adapt! Well worth the read."
I got this book as a gift when I moved to Utah. Four years later and it has traveled to every corner of the state with us. The author is from Utah and gives a great narrative on the different areas. There are great restaurants and awesome hiking trails mentioned. Sadly the binding glue failed on the book a couple years ago so I was on here looking for a new edition. Also At ten years old some of the information is a little dated.
"While traveling I bought this at a bookstore in the airport. I wish I had read the reviews before purchasing. It is a very touching story and it is a good read, but the over use of the ""F"" word just didn't set well with me. I can handle most mild swearing, but this was way too much. I feel Matt could have told his story just as well without it. I have heard that you can tell the intelligence of a person by their language....."
"This is an excellent guide to practical information on the district of Goa, and the city of Mumbai. It describes both places with recommendations on hotels, sight-seeing, local customs and travel, but is short on history and other background information. The section on Goa is a bit more elaborate than the one on Mumbai. An excellent value for the price. I purchased a used volume (2009) and found it quite adequate."
"INSPIRINGIn 58 short chapters Barbara Wolf and Margaret Anderson offer descriptions of worldwide opportunities to help our world and ourselves in an amazing variety of ways. The truly international book is diffused with their personal experiences of helping others as they travelled extensively over many years. It is complete with names, addresses and WEB sites for contacting a wide variety of people and organizations. From a globally known pharmacy in the Amazon that sells medicine from rain forest medicinal plants to information about the Global Youth Action network, WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP OUR WORLD has something to offer every reader.Shirley Andrews, author, Concord, MA"
"I first read this book over 25 years ago while traveling in Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, Utah, New Mexico, and Colorado. A trip I have made 14 times. I have also read stand-alone biographies of most of the great mountain men; Jedediah Smith, Hugh Glass, Jim Bridger, Kit Carson, Joe Meeks, Tom McDonald, and many more. I donated my collection of mountain men/indian biographies (over 30 volumes in all) to our local library.If you want to know more about these fascinating men and those times, this is by far the best and most readable place to begin."
"The Travel Bug series is a charming collection of books that will enchant readers of all ages: young, not-so-young, and anywhere in between. The characters - Buzworth and Nelson - seem very different at first glance, but soon learn through their adventures that their diversity is what brings them together. They become dependent on each other for their survival throughout the trials the harsh winter months bring them, and they soon become inseparable friends - an idea we could all learn from.The Travel Bug books will soon become a firm favourite with all readers and a regular request as a bedtime story.Mark - Angel Editing"
"Charles Kuralt's adventures to nearly every corner of the world are most entertaining and at the same time very heartfelt.His story telling of so many places and the people he encounters leaves one envious of his occupation.We read of his early beginnings in journalism and then resulting assignments to various parts of the globe...the Viet Nam War, Brazil, Africa, Japan, Russia, etc.Kuralt's genius shines when he does his travels in the United States...the back roads. For those who remember his ""On the Road"" episodes and Sunday morning programs will not be disappointed. For those who are not familiar with Kuralt, this will be a welcoming read."
"Dear 20somethings, 30somethings, 40somethings, 50somethings, and Everyone-somethings:You will adore this book. It's entertaining, hilarious, and lighthearted. Faith's character is real and sassy -- she takes her raw dreams and transforms them into realistic possibility. By the end of this book, you will be rooting for her and her success. Great summer read -- by the beach, at the pool, while traveling, or just hanging out."
"We (men) sometimes think we knw what we are doing. Driving to someplace w/o a map will force us to pull over and ask for direction, but the Bible acts like a GPS (but better). It give us solid roads to travel on, allowing you/me to bypass pot holes in life (sins). This book is a tool to help men travel well in the jounery of life. I/we will be using this book as a Bible study. I'm lookiing fwd to it. Blessing to you in ur growth for a better CHRIST like life in a sinfull world. kj"
"This brand new addition from Frommer's is chock full of info you'll want, to make your ""in the near future"" visit to Alaska a real treat. Within it's 550 pages, you'll find up-to-date information covering nearly everything you'll need, and more! They have even thrown in a new useful pull-out map. The text is easy to follow, and helps you avoid some of the common pit-falls tourists make. It features eleven tables-of-contents, and over 20 easy to use, new maps. Check some of the other Alaska books,and I think you'll agree that you can't go wrong with Frommer's latest edition on Alaska. Happy and safe travels !!"
"I was a bit skeptical at first, but this story quickly draws you in, and it only gets better! It starts off simply enough, with a small group assembling to save the world. However, before you know it, there's a hurricane and the first character (a king) you meet dies! The knights travel on to discover islands of gargantuan monsters guarding dwarven caves, a race of winged beings with bad tempers, four pillars that hold up the sky, and a literal edge of the earth that you can fall right off of (and somebody who does)!Torjen is the first part of a trilogy, and I can't wait to read parts 2 and 3! Danny Cove sets the bar even higher for fantasy authors to aspire towards."
"This book is a delightful read. It mixes absurdity with real insight into the Parisians...As a frequent traveler to my favorite city, this is a great book for the air flight or to read in the evening after a day of wandering the City of Light. It both criticizes the Parisians and helps one laugh at attitudes. If you'd like something light and fun to read, both men and woman will enjoy this book!"
"""Threads of Life"" is like music to me, for there is a song for every mood and emotion. There is comfort and hope in knowing that someone else has traveled the same road and found hope and healing. It may not be exactly the same circumstance as the Author, but all the same emotions are present. My favorite is ""Frozen"" it touched me deeply. Now not just a song will come to mind when I feel one of these strong emotions, but the words of Jessica Kristie will draw me back to her book to once again find I am not alone."
"Good book for a tourist in a foreign country. Unfortunately, it didn't meet my needs. I would recommend this book to anyone who is traveling abroad, but if you're looking for something that offers more general phrases in everyday situations, than this isn't a good choice. There wasn't much there that I might use at work while conversing with my Latino coworkers. I can't say it's a bad book; it just didn't fulfill my expectations."
"This book contains alot of information about the entire park. Details are given about roads to travel on, weather conditions you might encounter at different times of year, places to eat and hike to, and even some road trips. The information so detailed that you can trust it as a handy guide as you travel the park. The other nice thing about the book is that it includes areas to see that you would probably never think of if all you did was take the Going to the Sun Road. There is so much more to explore in addition to that."
"It was an o.k. overview. The bias of some of the writers, though, seemed to come through, with tips on the best pubs and bars and higher priced restaurants but less on castles, ruins, abbeys, economical b&bs. Lonely Planet has always helped me economize when traveling with less expensive,though quirky accommodations and restaurants, so I was not completely satisfied with what this one had to offer.In addition, it was not as user friendly as some other publications, necessitating one to jump around from map to map when planning a tour itinerary."
"[[ASIN:0972386661 Putting God Into Einstein's Equations: Energy of the Soul]]I started off with Weiss- Past lives, advanced to Newton-Spirit World, and finally Jerry Pollock has gone where no one else has dared to travel, as he has explored past lives and the spirit world thru direct telepathic communication. One must keep an open mind as Jerry is brutally honest about his life which to me makes him real and honest as he speaks to the reader. Having read books by Weiss and Newton, I have progressed in my thinking whereby I am totally open to what Jerry has written. Take the next step and keep an open mind and you will be exposed to new concepts and ideas."
"This is book two in the series Witches and Warlocks. Vance and Portia's characters are maturing, traveling from their small town out of state and to exotic places, and new people are falling into the trap of Damien, Vance's evil father. They form new alliances and discover the secrets run deep and are sickly. I like that Portia is learning her self worth. She's getting a backbone and kicking back. Every time I thought the suspense was slowing down, it rose to new heights."
"The work in question is particularly appealing to physicians, as they have experienced what Dr. London is describing, having traveled the same road through college and medical school and private practice. His wit is keen and often it makes the reader laugh out loud . . . nearly unable to stop. Patients will also enjoy it, but the common understanding of physicians makes M.D.'s the real target of this book."
"My wife and I initially looked for a book to find 'off the beaten path' type places withing a few hours for weekend trips and stumbled upon this book. I doubt we'll travel all 50 states, but its sure fun to look at all the things that each state has to offer. Its laid out and informative enough to just have as a book to browse through even if you don't plan to travel with it. The only down side is that it covers so much territory that the destinations are often far apart, so you can't really plan a trip around it. Good supplement to get the ideas flowing though. Nice book and a real bargain!"
"Name dropping, with just some adjectives here and there to make a text.8 pages on average for each Age/House/Dynasty, with a short sketch of the relationships between the different family members, before the author moves to the next chapter.I bought this book to discover the story of Scotland that I am ignorant about, but I won't make it with Tranter's book. Frankly, I found the History part of my travel guide more relevant and readable than this.Fortunately, the author do not bother us with the dates. The sole good point of this book."

Mature woman would love this read......I just have one question, what happened after the wedding, Leah? A sequel, I hope!

segmented_data.interview_data: I first read this book over 25 years ago while traveling in Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, Utah, New Mexico, and Colorado. A trip I have made 14 times. I have also read stand-alone biographies of most of the great mountain men; Jedediah Smith, Hugh Glass, Jim Bridger, Kit Carson, Joe Meeks, Tom McDonald, and many more. I donated my collection of mountain men/indian biographies (over 30 volumes in all) to our local library.If you want to know more about these fascinating men and those times, this is by far the best and most readable place to begin.

segmented_data.interview_data: The Travel Bug series is a charming collection of books that will enchant readers of all ages: young, not-so-young, and anywhere in between. The characters - Buzworth and Nelson - seem very different at first glance, but soon learn through their adventures that their diversity is what brings them together. They become dependent on each other for their survival throughout the trials the harsh winter months bring them, and they soon become inseparable friends - an idea we could all learn from.The Travel Bug books will soon become a firm favourite with all readers and a regular request as a bedtime story.Mark - Angel Editing

segmented_data.interview_data: Charles Kuralt's adventures to nearly every corner of the world are most entertaining and at the same time very heartfelt.His story telling of so many places and the people he encounters leaves one envious of his occupation.We read of his early beginnings in journalism and then resulting assignments to various parts of the globe...the Viet Nam War, Brazil, Africa, Japan, Russia, etc.Kuralt's genius shines when he does his travels in the United States...the back roads. For those who remember his "On the Road" episodes and Sunday morning programs will not be disappointed. For those who are not familiar with Kuralt, this will be a welcoming read.

segmented_data.interview_data: This brand new addition from Frommer's is chock full of info you'll want, to make your "in the near future" visit to Alaska a real treat. Within it's 550 pages, you'll find up-to-date information covering nearly everything you'll need, and more! They have even thrown in a new useful pull-out map. The text is easy to follow, and helps you avoid some of the common pit-falls tourists make. It features eleven tables-of-contents, and over 20 easy to use, new maps. Check some of the other Alaska books,and I think you'll agree that you can't go wrong with Frommer's latest edition on Alaska. Happy and safe travels !!

segmented_data.interview_data: I was a bit skeptical at first, but this story quickly draws you in, and it only gets better! It starts off simply enough, with a small group assembling to save the world. However, before you know it, there's a hurricane and the first character (a king) you meet dies! The knights travel on to discover islands of gargantuan monsters guarding dwarven caves, a race of winged beings with bad tempers, four pillars that hold up the sky, and a literal edge of the earth that you can fall right off of (and somebody who does)!Torjen is the first part of a trilogy, and I can't wait to read parts 2 and 3! Danny Cove sets the bar even higher for fantasy authors to aspire towards.

segmented_data.interview_data: My wife and I initially looked for a book to find 'off the beaten path' type places withing a few hours for weekend trips and stumbled upon this book. I doubt we'll travel all 50 states, but its sure fun to look at all the things that each state has to offer. Its laid out and informative enough to just have as a book to browse through even if you don't plan to travel with it. The only down side is that it covers so much territory that the destinations are often far apart, so you can't really plan a trip around it. Good supplement to get the ideas flowing though. Nice book and a real bargain!

input_docs:
"This books is great in multiple ways. First of all, it presents all of the versions of the argument spoken about in the text in a way that will deepen one's understanding of the cosmological arguments that have been given by the great thinkers through history. Second, it will spark one's interest in researching the topic even further. Third, it is a great companion book to any philosophy of religion course that takes a look at the cosmological argument. As a student of philosophy, I give it two thumbs up."
"This is a real masterpiece, and a must-read for anyone interested in American history, trees, the environment, or simply looking for a page-turner. Rutkow manages to make the fascinating and unknown history come alive, to turn dense, rigorous research into enjoyable prose. Using trees as a lens to view American history was a groundbreaking and ambitious goal that was brilliantly executed. I'm ready for volume II!"
"I am not crazy about the way this author writes, didn't like it in her first book either, it is a little too boring. But the content materials of her books are definitely worth reading, very refreshingly American--no nonsense, good hearted, resourceful, hard working people with wicked sense of humor, constantly adapting to challenges, constantly overcoming obstacles, improvising and inventing ways to utilize whatever resources available. These are no whiners! In my life where the sense of discontent often blinds me from seeing the bountiful reasons for gratitude, this book put me in place and I am grateful to the author for sharing the history of her grandmother."
"I love this book. With color photos, maps, and helpful descriptions of what to do, where to eat and stay, and how to get there, this guidebook is a pleasure to read. It gives suggestions for countless trips of one day to two weeks, detailing everything there is to see and do, how much time is required at each stop, and how to get to the next destination.The book can be a bit confusing, since one attraction may be listed in many places under different side trips, but reading the entire book page by page is a joy, at once both exhilarating and exhausting, as you daydream of seeing all the beauty, charm, and history Great Britain has to offer. Highly recommended."
"After thoroughly reading this book, I have to say that it achieves two important things. The first is that it breaks down the issue of fatalism in such a way that is easy to understand, and yet it does not sacrifice truth at the altar of understanding. The second thing that it achieves is that it explains both good and bad proposed solutions to the problem. To conclude, Bill Craig has done a masterful job of explicating the issue.If one is looking for another book written on this subject by the same author that is more technical and rigorous, see Craig's ""Divine Foreknowledge and Human Freedom"" in Brill's Studies in Intellectual History."
"This book displays history and mythology in a very unusual, yet good way. I really liked this book because it shows the religious and cultural value of India. This book was about Valkmiki and Hanuman's Ramayan. Valmiki wrote his version of Ramayan and asked other people how they liked it. They all enjoyed reading it. However, naarad said that he read a better version of Rayaman written by Hanuman. When Valmiki read this version of Ramayan, which was written on leaves, he started to cry. Hanuman took these banana leaves and ate them.I definitely love this book and would recommend it to anyone who likes historical books."
"I'm an investment advisor.I recommend this book to all laypeople who want to self-educate.In my opinion, this may be the best investing book for laypeople ever written.The first part was kind of thick, in my opinion (it is about history of investing and the risk/reward tradeoff). But if you slog through those first few dozen pages, you will be richly rewarded by the rest of the book.Only other books that come close to this book, in my opinion, for self-education of laypeople are:- Common Sense on Mutual Funds, by Bogle, and- A Random Walk Down Wall Street, by Malkiel"
"I purchased this book because I had watched Professor Lerer's History of the English Language contribution to The Learning Company's Great Courses series of DVDs. The book did not disappoint; it is if anything even more informative and absorbing than was the DVD.I recommend [[ASIN:023113794X Inventing English: A Portable History of the Language]] to anyone interested in the many *whys* of our language. Because English has evolved (and is still evolving) from so many other languages, its history is especially intriguing.Seth Lerer writes English beautifully, and I believe you will be as delighted by this book as was I!"
"Leave it to Hugh Hewitt to tell it like it is. This is the book I was looking for. I wanted to learn some real things about Romeny, and did not want to be bombarded with left wing poison. Its impossible to watch the news without getting the newscasters slant on Mitt, and scoffing about his religion, while ignoring Obama and his Muslim history. One has to look around to find something outside of the mainstream."
"If there is any doubt with regard to the true nature of Communism, this book will inform the reader as to just how evil it is. In the century it has been practiced, from the Soviet Union to Cuba, the slaughter has been hideous. Conservively 100 million people have been slaughtered. This book tells the real history of this vile creed. It is a complete reference manual to Communism and serious scholars should have it in their libraries."
"I thought the book was good, but a little confusing at times. For example when the chapter of Alexander and India it talks about the battle of Hydaspes River and then all of a sudden goes back to the start of the invasion and then talks about the battle again. I learned that Alexander was not only an amazing tactician, but also a kind man to some people. I would recommend this book to those who like ancient history and have enough time on their hands to read it. Yes I would say this book is ""Important"" for people who have been able to achieve so much should be remembered and this book goes into great detail of Alexander."
"This is an excellent picture book of the lovely chalet; I just wish it had some floor plan measurements; in my fifties now, I grew up with parents that never spoke about the war, no one did; Anyway, the colour pictures bring the building and it's history to life, and despite it's owner, it was a lovely building, with historical and tragic significance; I understand why it had to be destroyed, and why it can't be rebuilt, but it was a lovely building. Oh, and my book was sealed in plastic but missing the english translation, wish the publisher would post a download link."
"I had heard many good things about Guerber's histories and assumed that an updated and expanded history of the ancient Near East would be even better than the original. My mistake! Christine Miller rewrote Guerber's original to reflect her fundamentalist Protestant beliefs, including that Creation occurred in 4004 BC and that the patriarchs, starting with Adam, wrote down their own family history and handed the sacred books down from one generation to the next. The history of other societies in the Near East is changed to accommodate Miller's chronology. If you are looking for biblical history, stick with the original Guerber."
"Alan Moore is a fascinating subject for an interview. Not only are his works among the finest in comics history, unique in their depth, conviction and intellect, but Moore as a person is similarly one-of-a-kind. The interviews collected here present Moore on a range of subjects and span most of his career. The book is well worth the attention of anyone interested in Moore's work, or comics in general. A handy tome featuring some of Moore's finest interviews, this collection is a welcome addition to any Alan Moore library. Buy it."
"I highly recommend this book to any enthusiast, master and any belt rank who is learning this amazing martial arts, As I am! Very truthful, open and honest. No sugar coating here! Great insight to the history and making of Taekwondo as well as fulfilling the promise of the title of this book by relating ancient knowledge to the modern world we live in. It gives reader a 'bird's eye' view of everything associated it with in general. It goes over everything and I mean everything in a readable and understandable way! Really, it's so amazing I can not find the right words. Honestly, you just need to read it."
"I bought this gift for my sister-in-law because she is as dotty over Downton Abbey as I am. She said that it is a very ""lush"" book, and the pictures are exquisite. She said that you can make out the details of the costumes, and that it does give background information about the show and the history of its origins. Because it is a gift, I do not know how much detail it goes into about history, but I do know from the way my sister-in-law described the pictures, that she was pleased with all of the detail they picked up, especially the details in the costumes. I'm pleased that the gift pleased her. She's a very nice person."
"The Browns have written a fascinating book about their history and marital life. As a faithful viewer of the mesmerizing Sister Wives, I thought I knew their story but I did not. They have forged a family through financial hardship, tears, and buckets of blood under the bridge. ""The family is the test of freedom, because the family is the only thing that the free man makes for himself and by himself."" -- C.K. Chesterton, 1919"
"I don't know why our professor likes this book. It has nothing more than any other book on the US Government. That is to say that the basic history of American Government is pretty straightforward; we've only been around 200 years as a country. So the book has a lot of filler in it. The real zinger is the price. I paid $180 for this book at the campus bookstore. Amazon has it for around $160. The buyback here is $26 bucks! $26 bucks!Everything covered in this book is basic high school civics. The high price goes to pay the very high ""tax"" of going to college."
"I suppose the literature that satires Australia and the likes for Western readers is misunderstood; background in history and anthropology is a plus -- I mean reading Self isn't like applying body lotion to determine if one likes its smell, tackiness and synthesis...if you don't get Will maybe its an aquired taste. I think his SATIRE is tremendously funny and fun poking at all those humans who like to imagine they are better than ordinary humans."
"One should know that pages 2-29 are missing from this edition. These pages crucially cover the early life and conversion of Frances to the Catholic faith. I called Amazon and they sent me a replacement copy in 2 days. Unfortunately that copy was missing the same pages. It seems all books in this print run missed these pages. Look for another edition if you want St. Francis's early history. Otherwise this book contains all three ""lives"" of St. Francis and is compact and fairly easy to read, although later translations (year 2000 or so) are even easier to read."

It gives suggestions for countless trips of one day to two weeks, detailing everything there is to see and do, how much time is required at each stop, and how to get to the next destination.The book can be a bit confusing, since one attraction may be listed in many places under different side trips, but reading the entire book page by page is a joy, at once both exhilarating and exhausting, as you daydream of seeing all the beauty, charm, and history Great Britain has to offer. Highly recommended.

segmented_data.interview_data: After thoroughly reading this book, I have to say that it achieves two important things. The first is that it breaks down the issue of fatalism in such a way that is easy to understand, and yet it does not sacrifice truth at the altar of understanding. The second thing that it achieves is that it explains both good and bad proposed solutions to the problem. To conclude, Bill Craig has done a masterful job of explicating the issue.If one is looking for another book written on this subject by the same author that is more technical and rigorous, see Craig's "Divine Foreknowledge and Human Freedom" in Brill's Studies in Intellectual History.

segmented_data.interview_data: I had heard many good things about Guerber's histories and assumed that an updated and expanded history of the ancient Near East would be even better than the original. My mistake! Christine Miller rewrote Guerber's original to reflect her fundamentalist Protestant beliefs, including that Creation occurred in 4004 BC and that the patriarchs, starting with Adam, wrote down their own family history and handed the sacred books down from one generation to the next. The history of other societies in the Near East is changed to accommodate Miller's chronology. If you are looking for biblical history, stick with the original Guerber.

"How A Business Works was an excellent book to read as I began my first semester as a college student. Although my goal is to major in Business, I started my semester off with no idea of even the basic guidelines a Business undergrad should know. This book describes in detail every aspect dealing with business relations, and I enjoyed reading it. It felt great going to my additional business classes prepared and knowledgeable on the subject they were describing. Very well written, Professor Haeberle! I recommend this book to anyone and everyone who would like additional knowledge pertaining to business matters."
This is an inspirational and insightful book that is well written and contains some profound methods to improve your thinking and improve your life. The ideas and methods that Robbins suggests are not just theory but I can attest from personal experience that they really work as I have successfully used some of the concepts. Fried summarizes the best personal development strategies and combines it with brilliant business principles to help you become the entrepreneur of your own existence. I LOVED it.
"Easy read. A tale of burning and flying, acceptance and soaring. I applaud this book describing a successful businessman who decides to chuck it all in hopes of finding out the big WHY. An almost believable story that combines humanness with spirituality, ya know, super oneness and love. I appreciated the author's command of the written word. It is alerting us to become aware we are on a journey of light and love. It's about meditation and where it can lead us. A story built around seeking, Thank you Jacob for sharing this teaching with us."
Whether just starting out with a new business or being a seasoned owner pregnancy will throw some curve balls. This book helps you navigate through business and pregnancy and how they relate to one another. Must read for women who own their own businesses and want/are starting a family.**Disclosure - I received a copy of this book for review purposes. However all opinions are my own. You can see the full review on Astheygrowup.com**
"I read a lot of motivational, business and self help books. This one is nothing like the others. There's a ton of great advice in this book, much of it is counter to conventional wisdom. I found it refreshing to read because the author is not afraid to say things that may be unpopular. My only real complaint is that it is such an easy book to read (feels like you are in the room listening to him speak)that you may end up flying through some of the great points without them registering fully. Read this one with a highlighter in hand."
"Ken Segall's book is a much better and easier read than Isaacson's work. Following the lead of its title, the book is easy to follow with many interesting anecdotes about Steve Jobs and his competitors while instructing us on the art of Simplicity. Somehow, that subject has become lost to the extent that many of us overlook it in our personal and business lives. Thanks for the interesting and well-written lesson, Ken."
"Berardinelli is a trial lawyer who took Allstate to court and won. This is the corrupt auto insurance industry laid bare. All of the major companies bought the McKinsey & Co. business model that ensures they pay out the least amount on claims in order to maximize profits and executive bonuses.Want to know which are the most corrupt of the corrupt? Just look at the companies who spend the most money on TV and radio advertising. How else can they afford to pay for it all?Sadly, this book is widely unknown but it is must-reading for anyone with car insurance or in the market to buy car insurance. Caveat emptor indeed."
"Love Works is timely. In our economic climate, leaders can assume that they need to choose between profit and people. Joel Manby's thesis--backed up by decades of successful leadership--is different. A business run on timeless principles of love, like patience and kindness and truthfulness, can improve its bottom line and its relationships at the same time. Simply put, love actually works. This will be a refreshing read for anyone who feels that in order to succeed they must be a different person at work from who they truly want to be."
This book finally details what life was like in the trenches in the War on Terror and the brave men and women involved in the fight. It also provides credible insight into the politics of the situation and how politicians manipulated truth for political gain and cover. It's saying something that a man like Rodriguez trained in the art of deception and lying is more credible than the former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi. Her blatant lies regarding her knowledge and approval of these events are chilling. We are lucky to have hero's like Rodriguez providing an inside look at what is a dangerous business.;
"This book should be required reading in High School. By the time we pass this mark most people have very bad money habits.Sensible, salient and sincere, Roland explains investing in a way that makes you feel you are sitting down having a cup of coffee with him. Debunking several common myths of investing he drives home the need to make it your business to invest correctly or find someone not only qualified - but also someone with character. This is a fabulous book and by implementing just a few of his suggestions I will be growing my portfolio substantially!"
"I work for a Franchising company and I am also a Business school graduate and I found this graphic novel fun to read and also extremely informative. No teacher that I had in while I was in school ever gave me a text book that was as intriguing to read as this one! I was very interested when I heard that it was a graphic novel and albeit a bit skeptical, but once I started reading it I had to close my office door and keep reading it. I want to hand a copy to all the potential franchisees that come in our office!"
"Mark Griffin has blended his experience in both the secular business and the Christian cultures to provide a guidebook for business leaders who aspire to bring an ""eternal perspective"" to their workplaces. Most books in this genre emphasize the ""Core Value"" approach, but the author has gone the next step to provide realistic and practical implementation tools to weave those values into the fabric of their businesses. I would highly recommend this very practical guidebook for business leaders or owners who wish to build their faith into their workplace."
"I bought this book because it was required for a class I was taking. It explains how to market a business on Google through Adwords (the Ads you see the side of a Google Search) and Ad placement (You can pay for your ad to be placed page one rather than page 20 of a Google Search). While the images in the book are helpful, everything in this book can be found by simply doing a Google search.SideBar: Running a Google ad campaign is VERY expensive. I would not recommend this type of marketing campaign for a small business, as it is easy to blow through $500 in a few weeks."
"If as a business leader, you care about things like ingenuity, innovation, and employees improvising creatively, you should read this book. I work in the healthcare profession and found myself nodding and agreeing vigorously with each point made. If only the senior most leaders at my company would read this! The best elements of Jugaad are 1) the flexibility of the concept, 2) the ability to tailor Jugaad to given products and initiatives, and 3) the fact that it brings some autonomy among employees and entrepreneurial spirit back into the workplace."
"I have utilized Fred's model to create an information marketing business that is now producing thousands of dollars per year. What you get with Fred is bare-bones, no-fluff useful information that you can immediately implement in your own business. This book is great because it provides an easy to follow step-by-step system on how to create, market and sell your information products.Buy this book if you are serious about improving your business!"
"Every lawyer needs to generate business, so this book should be added to every lawyer's library. The sales principles in this book are universal and can be readily applied to the practice of law and the sales of legal services. In fact, the analytic approach to sales strategy revealed in this book should be especially appealing to lawyers, as we strive to provide unexpected value to our clients and expand our opportunities with both existing and future clients."
"I loved this book. It is told through the eyes of a young boy observing life in the streets and tenements of the Bronx, while trying to save his father from his fate. Rickie and his ancient, emotional grandmother run a bookie business from their tiny kitchen, and Ricky is condemned to stay home to answer the phone in case bets are called in. The characters are richly described and so real that you can recognize them. And yet they are also dreamlike and Dickensian in size - at times absurd and comical, and at other times dark and evil. A must on your summer reading list!"
"As with many of the books I am working through, I am surprised I never read this one. It was short and enjoyable, full of interesting ideas. I am pretty sure however, that the cottage industry that adapts ""The Art of War"" to business, relationships, law, football, whatever else is full of crap. This book is about war and only an extreme bending of the author's words or cherry picking those words free of their context would make it apply elsewhere.Certainly not a science textbook, it has a few mistakes but I can see why the book continues to be read and studied after thousands of years. It was fun."
"There are many books on social media marketing still flooding the marketplace but this one rises above the rest. Shama lives and breathes social media and I know this because we both started blogging around the same time years back. She walks readers through understanding why social media is important and guides them from step to step explaining all the different ways you can make it work for your business. By reading this book, you'll be able to do more with less and stand out from the crowd."
"When I first purchased this book for class, I was surprised at how small it was in comparison to some of the other textbooks I had purchased for other business classes. But it shows that you don't have to have a huge book to learn about business. It is easy to read, understand and follow. It will be a great tool for anyone who is thinking about starting their own business or learning more about how businesses truly work."

input_docs:
"This books is great in multiple ways. First of all, it presents all of the versions of the argument spoken about in the text in a way that will deepen one's understanding of the cosmological arguments that have been given by the great thinkers through history. Second, it will spark one's interest in researching the topic even further. Third, it is a great companion book to any philosophy of religion course that takes a look at the cosmological argument. As a student of philosophy, I give it two thumbs up."
"This is a real masterpiece, and a must-read for anyone interested in American history, trees, the environment, or simply looking for a page-turner. Rutkow manages to make the fascinating and unknown history come alive, to turn dense, rigorous research into enjoyable prose. Using trees as a lens to view American history was a groundbreaking and ambitious goal that was brilliantly executed. I'm ready for volume II!"
"I am not crazy about the way this author writes, didn't like it in her first book either, it is a little too boring. But the content materials of her books are definitely worth reading, very refreshingly American--no nonsense, good hearted, resourceful, hard working people with wicked sense of humor, constantly adapting to challenges, constantly overcoming obstacles, improvising and inventing ways to utilize whatever resources available. These are no whiners! In my life where the sense of discontent often blinds me from seeing the bountiful reasons for gratitude, this book put me in place and I am grateful to the author for sharing the history of her grandmother."
"I love this book. With color photos, maps, and helpful descriptions of what to do, where to eat and stay, and how to get there, this guidebook is a pleasure to read. It gives suggestions for countless trips of one day to two weeks, detailing everything there is to see and do, how much time is required at each stop, and how to get to the next destination.The book can be a bit confusing, since one attraction may be listed in many places under different side trips, but reading the entire book page by page is a joy, at once both exhilarating and exhausting, as you daydream of seeing all the beauty, charm, and history Great Britain has to offer. Highly recommended."
"After thoroughly reading this book, I have to say that it achieves two important things. The first is that it breaks down the issue of fatalism in such a way that is easy to understand, and yet it does not sacrifice truth at the altar of understanding. The second thing that it achieves is that it explains both good and bad proposed solutions to the problem. To conclude, Bill Craig has done a masterful job of explicating the issue.If one is looking for another book written on this subject by the same author that is more technical and rigorous, see Craig's ""Divine Foreknowledge and Human Freedom"" in Brill's Studies in Intellectual History."
"This book displays history and mythology in a very unusual, yet good way. I really liked this book because it shows the religious and cultural value of India. This book was about Valkmiki and Hanuman's Ramayan. Valmiki wrote his version of Ramayan and asked other people how they liked it. They all enjoyed reading it. However, naarad said that he read a better version of Rayaman written by Hanuman. When Valmiki read this version of Ramayan, which was written on leaves, he started to cry. Hanuman took these banana leaves and ate them.I definitely love this book and would recommend it to anyone who likes historical books."
"I'm an investment advisor.I recommend this book to all laypeople who want to self-educate.In my opinion, this may be the best investing book for laypeople ever written.The first part was kind of thick, in my opinion (it is about history of investing and the risk/reward tradeoff). But if you slog through those first few dozen pages, you will be richly rewarded by the rest of the book.Only other books that come close to this book, in my opinion, for self-education of laypeople are:- Common Sense on Mutual Funds, by Bogle, and- A Random Walk Down Wall Street, by Malkiel"
"I purchased this book because I had watched Professor Lerer's History of the English Language contribution to The Learning Company's Great Courses series of DVDs. The book did not disappoint; it is if anything even more informative and absorbing than was the DVD.I recommend [[ASIN:023113794X Inventing English: A Portable History of the Language]] to anyone interested in the many *whys* of our language. Because English has evolved (and is still evolving) from so many other languages, its history is especially intriguing.Seth Lerer writes English beautifully, and I believe you will be as delighted by this book as was I!"
"Leave it to Hugh Hewitt to tell it like it is. This is the book I was looking for. I wanted to learn some real things about Romeny, and did not want to be bombarded with left wing poison. Its impossible to watch the news without getting the newscasters slant on Mitt, and scoffing about his religion, while ignoring Obama and his Muslim history. One has to look around to find something outside of the mainstream."
"If there is any doubt with regard to the true nature of Communism, this book will inform the reader as to just how evil it is. In the century it has been practiced, from the Soviet Union to Cuba, the slaughter has been hideous. Conservively 100 million people have been slaughtered. This book tells the real history of this vile creed. It is a complete reference manual to Communism and serious scholars should have it in their libraries."
"I thought the book was good, but a little confusing at times. For example when the chapter of Alexander and India it talks about the battle of Hydaspes River and then all of a sudden goes back to the start of the invasion and then talks about the battle again. I learned that Alexander was not only an amazing tactician, but also a kind man to some people. I would recommend this book to those who like ancient history and have enough time on their hands to read it. Yes I would say this book is ""Important"" for people who have been able to achieve so much should be remembered and this book goes into great detail of Alexander."
"This is an excellent picture book of the lovely chalet; I just wish it had some floor plan measurements; in my fifties now, I grew up with parents that never spoke about the war, no one did; Anyway, the colour pictures bring the building and it's history to life, and despite it's owner, it was a lovely building, with historical and tragic significance; I understand why it had to be destroyed, and why it can't be rebuilt, but it was a lovely building. Oh, and my book was sealed in plastic but missing the english translation, wish the publisher would post a download link."
"I had heard many good things about Guerber's histories and assumed that an updated and expanded history of the ancient Near East would be even better than the original. My mistake! Christine Miller rewrote Guerber's original to reflect her fundamentalist Protestant beliefs, including that Creation occurred in 4004 BC and that the patriarchs, starting with Adam, wrote down their own family history and handed the sacred books down from one generation to the next. The history of other societies in the Near East is changed to accommodate Miller's chronology. If you are looking for biblical history, stick with the original Guerber."
"Alan Moore is a fascinating subject for an interview. Not only are his works among the finest in comics history, unique in their depth, conviction and intellect, but Moore as a person is similarly one-of-a-kind. The interviews collected here present Moore on a range of subjects and span most of his career. The book is well worth the attention of anyone interested in Moore's work, or comics in general. A handy tome featuring some of Moore's finest interviews, this collection is a welcome addition to any Alan Moore library. Buy it."
"I highly recommend this book to any enthusiast, master and any belt rank who is learning this amazing martial arts, As I am! Very truthful, open and honest. No sugar coating here! Great insight to the history and making of Taekwondo as well as fulfilling the promise of the title of this book by relating ancient knowledge to the modern world we live in. It gives reader a 'bird's eye' view of everything associated it with in general. It goes over everything and I mean everything in a readable and understandable way! Really, it's so amazing I can not find the right words. Honestly, you just need to read it."

In my life where the sense of discontent often blinds me from seeing the bountiful reasons for gratitude, this book put me in place and I am grateful to the author for sharing the history of her grandmother."
"I love this book. With color photos, maps, and helpful descriptions of what to do, where to eat and stay, and how to get there, this guidebook is a pleasure to read. It gives suggestions for countless trips of one day to two weeks, detailing everything there is to see and do, how much time is required at each stop, and how to get to the next destination.The book can be a bit confusing, since one attraction may be listed in many places under different side trips, but reading the entire book page by page is a joy, at once both exhilarating and exhausting, as you daydream of seeing all the beauty, charm, and history Great Britain has to offer. Highly recommended."
"After thoroughly reading this book, I have to say that it achieves two important things. The first is that it breaks down the issue of fatalism in such a way that is easy to understand, and yet it does not sacrifice truth at the altar of understanding. The second thing that it achieves is that it explains both good and bad proposed solutions to the problem. To conclude, Bill Craig has done a masterful job of explicating the issue.If one is looking for another book written on this subject by the same author that is more technical and rigorous, see Craig's ""Divine Foreknowledge and Human Freedom"" in Brill's Studies in Intellectual History."
"This book displays history and mythology in a very unusual, yet good way. I really liked this book because it shows the religious and cultural value of India. This book was about Valkmiki and Hanuman's Ramayan. Valmiki wrote his version of Ramayan and asked other people how they liked it. They all enjoyed reading it. However, naarad said that he read a better version of Rayaman written by Hanuman. When Valmiki read this version of Ramayan, which was written on leaves, he started to cry. Hanuman took these banana leaves and ate them.I definitely love this book and would recommend it to anyone who likes historical books."
"I'm an investment advisor.I recommend this book to all laypeople who want to self-educate.In my opinion, this may be the best investing book for laypeople ever written.The first part was kind of thick, in my opinion (it is about history of investing and the risk/reward tradeoff). But if you slog through those first few dozen pages, you will be richly rewarded by the rest of the book.Only other books that come close to this book, in my opinion, for self-education of laypeople are:- Common Sense on Mutual Funds, by Bogle, and- A Random Walk Down Wall Street, by Malkiel"
"I purchased this book because I had watched Professor Lerer's History of the English Language contribution to The Learning Company's Great Courses series of DVDs. The book did not disappoint; it is if anything even more informative and absorbing than was the DVD.I recommend [[ASIN:023113794X Inventing English: A Portable History of the Language]] to anyone interested in the many *whys* of our language. Because English has evolved (and is still evolving) from so many other languages, its history is especially intriguing.Seth Lerer writes English beautifully, and I believe you will be as delighted by this book as was I!"
"Leave it to Hugh Hewitt to tell it like it is. This is the book I was looking for. I wanted to learn some real things about Romeny, and did not want to be bombarded with left wing poison. Its impossible to watch the news without getting the newscasters slant on Mitt, and scoffing about his religion, while ignoring Obama and his Muslim history. One has to look around to find something outside of the mainstream."
"If there is any doubt with regard to the true nature of Communism, this book will inform the reader as to just how evil it is. In the century it has been practiced, from the Soviet Union to Cuba, the slaughter has been hideous. Conservively 100 million people have been slaughtered. This book tells the real history of this vile creed. It is a complete reference manual to Communism and serious scholars should have it in their libraries."
"I thought the book was good, but a little confusing at times. For example when the chapter of Alexander and India it talks about the battle of Hydaspes River and then all of a sudden goes back to the start of the invasion and then talks about the battle again. I learned that Alexander was not only an amazing tactician, but also a kind man to some people. I would recommend this book to those who like ancient history and have enough time on their hands to read it. Yes I would say this book is ""Important"" for people who have been able to achieve so much should be remembered and this book goes into great detail of Alexander."
"This is an excellent picture book of the lovely chalet; I just wish it had some floor plan measurements; in my fifties now, I grew up with parents that never spoke about the war, no one did; Anyway, the colour pictures bring the building and it's history to life, and despite it's owner, it was a lovely building, with historical and tragic significance; I understand why it had to be destroyed, and why it can't be rebuilt, but it was a lovely building. Oh, and my book was sealed in plastic but missing the english translation, wish the publisher would post a download link."
"I had heard many good things about Guerber's histories and assumed that an updated and expanded history of the ancient Near East would be even better than the original. My mistake! Christine Miller rewrote Guerber's original to reflect her fundamentalist Protestant beliefs, including that Creation occurred in 4004 BC and that the patriarchs, starting with Adam, wrote down their own family history and handed the sacred books down from one generation to the next. The history of other societies in the Near East is changed to accommodate Miller's chronology. If you are looking for biblical history, stick with the original Guerber."
"Alan Moore is a fascinating subject for an interview. Not only are his works among the finest in comics history, unique in their depth, conviction and intellect, but Moore as a person is similarly one-of-a-kind. The interviews collected here present Moore on a range of subjects and span most of his career. The book is well worth the attention of anyone interested in Moore's work, or comics in general. A handy tome featuring some of Moore's finest interviews, this collection is a welcome addition to any Alan Moore library. Buy it."
"I highly recommend this book to any enthusiast, master and any belt rank who is learning this amazing martial arts, As I am! Very truthful, open and honest. No sugar coating here! Great insight to the history and making of Taekwondo as well as fulfilling the promise of the title of this book by relating ancient knowledge to the modern world we live in. It gives reader a 'bird's eye' view of everything associated it with in general. It goes over everything and I mean everything in a readable and understandable way! Really, it's so amazing I can not find the right words. Honestly, you just need to read it."

Second, it will spark one's interest in researching the topic even further. Third, it is a great companion book to any philosophy of religion course that takes a look at the cosmological argument. As a student of philosophy, I give it two thumbs up.

name: Diffcoder Study 5
input_docs:
"How A Business Works was an excellent book to read as I began my first semester as a college student. Although my goal is to major in Business, I started my semester off with no idea of even the basic guidelines a Business undergrad should know. This book describes in detail every aspect dealing with business relations, and I enjoyed reading it. It felt great going to my additional business classes prepared and knowledgeable on the subject they were describing. Very well written, Professor Haeberle! I recommend this book to anyone and everyone who would like additional knowledge pertaining to business matters."
This is an inspirational and insightful book that is well written and contains some profound methods to improve your thinking and improve your life. The ideas and methods that Robbins suggests are not just theory but I can attest from personal experience that they really work as I have successfully used some of the concepts. Fried summarizes the best personal development strategies and combines it with brilliant business principles to help you become the entrepreneur of your own existence. I LOVED it.
"Easy read. A tale of burning and flying, acceptance and soaring. I applaud this book describing a successful businessman who decides to chuck it all in hopes of finding out the big WHY. An almost believable story that combines humanness with spirituality, ya know, super oneness and love. I appreciated the author's command of the written word. It is alerting us to become aware we are on a journey of light and love. It's about meditation and where it can lead us. A story built around seeking, Thank you Jacob for sharing this teaching with us."
Whether just starting out with a new business or being a seasoned owner pregnancy will throw some curve balls. This book helps you navigate through business and pregnancy and how they relate to one another. Must read for women who own their own businesses and want/are starting a family.**Disclosure - I received a copy of this book for review purposes. However all opinions are my own. You can see the full review on Astheygrowup.com**
"I read a lot of motivational, business and self help books. This one is nothing like the others. There's a ton of great advice in this book, much of it is counter to conventional wisdom. I found it refreshing to read because the author is not afraid to say things that may be unpopular. My only real complaint is that it is such an easy book to read (feels like you are in the room listening to him speak)that you may end up flying through some of the great points without them registering fully. Read this one with a highlighter in hand."
"Ken Segall's book is a much better and easier read than Isaacson's work. Following the lead of its title, the book is easy to follow with many interesting anecdotes about Steve Jobs and his competitors while instructing us on the art of Simplicity. Somehow, that subject has become lost to the extent that many of us overlook it in our personal and business lives. Thanks for the interesting and well-written lesson, Ken."
"Berardinelli is a trial lawyer who took Allstate to court and won. This is the corrupt auto insurance industry laid bare. All of the major companies bought the McKinsey & Co. business model that ensures they pay out the least amount on claims in order to maximize profits and executive bonuses.Want to know which are the most corrupt of the corrupt? Just look at the companies who spend the most money on TV and radio advertising. How else can they afford to pay for it all?Sadly, this book is widely unknown but it is must-reading for anyone with car insurance or in the market to buy car insurance. Caveat emptor indeed."
"Love Works is timely. In our economic climate, leaders can assume that they need to choose between profit and people. Joel Manby's thesis--backed up by decades of successful leadership--is different. A business run on timeless principles of love, like patience and kindness and truthfulness, can improve its bottom line and its relationships at the same time. Simply put, love actually works. This will be a refreshing read for anyone who feels that in order to succeed they must be a different person at work from who they truly want to be."
This book finally details what life was like in the trenches in the War on Terror and the brave men and women involved in the fight. It also provides credible insight into the politics of the situation and how politicians manipulated truth for political gain and cover. It's saying something that a man like Rodriguez trained in the art of deception and lying is more credible than the former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi. Her blatant lies regarding her knowledge and approval of these events are chilling. We are lucky to have hero's like Rodriguez providing an inside look at what is a dangerous business.;
"This book should be required reading in High School. By the time we pass this mark most people have very bad money habits.Sensible, salient and sincere, Roland explains investing in a way that makes you feel you are sitting down having a cup of coffee with him. Debunking several common myths of investing he drives home the need to make it your business to invest correctly or find someone not only qualified - but also someone with character. This is a fabulous book and by implementing just a few of his suggestions I will be growing my portfolio substantially!"
"I work for a Franchising company and I am also a Business school graduate and I found this graphic novel fun to read and also extremely informative. No teacher that I had in while I was in school ever gave me a text book that was as intriguing to read as this one! I was very interested when I heard that it was a graphic novel and albeit a bit skeptical, but once I started reading it I had to close my office door and keep reading it. I want to hand a copy to all the potential franchisees that come in our office!"
"Mark Griffin has blended his experience in both the secular business and the Christian cultures to provide a guidebook for business leaders who aspire to bring an ""eternal perspective"" to their workplaces. Most books in this genre emphasize the ""Core Value"" approach, but the author has gone the next step to provide realistic and practical implementation tools to weave those values into the fabric of their businesses. I would highly recommend this very practical guidebook for business leaders or owners who wish to build their faith into their workplace."
"I bought this book because it was required for a class I was taking. It explains how to market a business on Google through Adwords (the Ads you see the side of a Google Search) and Ad placement (You can pay for your ad to be placed page one rather than page 20 of a Google Search). While the images in the book are helpful, everything in this book can be found by simply doing a Google search.SideBar: Running a Google ad campaign is VERY expensive. I would not recommend this type of marketing campaign for a small business, as it is easy to blow through $500 in a few weeks."
"If as a business leader, you care about things like ingenuity, innovation, and employees improvising creatively, you should read this book. I work in the healthcare profession and found myself nodding and agreeing vigorously with each point made. If only the senior most leaders at my company would read this! The best elements of Jugaad are 1) the flexibility of the concept, 2) the ability to tailor Jugaad to given products and initiatives, and 3) the fact that it brings some autonomy among employees and entrepreneurial spirit back into the workplace."
"I have utilized Fred's model to create an information marketing business that is now producing thousands of dollars per year. What you get with Fred is bare-bones, no-fluff useful information that you can immediately implement in your own business. This book is great because it provides an easy to follow step-by-step system on how to create, market and sell your information products.Buy this book if you are serious about improving your business!"

segmented_data.interview_data: Love Works is timely. In our economic climate, leaders can assume that they need to choose between profit and people. Joel Manby's thesis--backed up by decades of successful leadership--is different. A business run on timeless principles of love, like patience and kindness and truthfulness, can improve its bottom line and its relationships at the same time. Simply put, love actually works. This will be a refreshing read for anyone who feels that in order to succeed they must be a different person at work from who they truly want to be.

segmented_data.interview_data: I bought this book because it was required for a class I was taking. It explains how to market a business on Google through Adwords (the Ads you see the side of a Google Search) and Ad placement (You can pay for your ad to be placed page one rather than page 20 of a Google Search). While the images in the book are helpful, everything in this book can be found by simply doing a Google search.SideBar: Running a Google ad campaign is VERY expensive. I would not recommend this type of marketing campaign for a small business, as it is easy to blow through $500 in a few weeks.
